title: Getting Started with Docker and Containers
excerpt: Docker is a platform for developing, shipping, and running applications in containers. Containers allow you to package an application with all of its dependencies.
content:
## What is Docker?

Docker is a platform for developing, shipping, and running applications in containers. Containers allow you to package an application with all of its dependencies into a standardized unit for software development.

![Docker Logo](https://placehold.co/600x300.png)

This solves the "it works on my machine" problem.

### Basic Docker Commands
- `docker build -t my-app .` - Builds an image from a Dockerfile.
- `docker run -p 8080:80 my-app` - Runs the container and maps port 80 inside the container to port 8080 on the host.

title: CI/CD with GitHub Actions
excerpt: GitHub Actions makes it easy to automate all your software workflows, now with world-class CI/CD. Build, test, and deploy your code right from GitHub.
content:
## Automate Your Workflow

Continuous Integration (CI) and Continuous Deployment (CD) are practices that automate the process of software delivery. GitHub Actions allows you to create workflows defined in a YAML file directly in your repository. These workflows can be triggered by events like a push or a pull request.

title: Introduction to Kubernetes
excerpt: Kubernetes, also known as K8s, is an open-source system for automating deployment, scaling, and management of containerized applications.
content:
## Container Orchestration

While Docker allows you to create and run containers, Kubernetes helps you manage them at scale. It handles service discovery, load balancing, self-healing, and rolling updates across a cluster of machines, making it the industry standard for container orchestration.

title: Infrastructure as Code with Terraform
excerpt: Terraform is an open-source infrastructure as code software tool that enables you to safely and predictably create, change, and improve infrastructure.
content:
## Declarative Infrastructure

Infrastructure as Code (IaC) is the practice of managing and provisioning computing infrastructure through machine-readable definition files, rather than physical hardware configuration or interactive configuration tools. Terraform uses a declarative language called HCL (HashiCorp Configuration Language) to define your desired infrastructure state. It then figures out how to achieve that state, creating a plan that you can review before applying.

title: Monitoring with Prometheus and Grafana
excerpt: Prometheus is a time-series database for monitoring, and Grafana is a visualization tool for creating dashboards. Together, they form a powerful open-source monitoring stack.
content:
## See What's Happening

Observability is crucial for understanding the health of your systems. Prometheus scrapes metrics from your applications and stores them in a time-series database. Grafana then connects to Prometheus (and other data sources) to let you build rich, interactive dashboards to visualize those metrics, helping you spot trends and troubleshoot issues.

title: Managing Secrets in Your Applications
excerpt: Never commit secrets like API keys or passwords directly into your codebase. Learn about best practices for managing secrets using environment variables and dedicated secret management tools.
content:
## Don't Commit Secrets!

Hardcoding secrets in your code is a major security risk. Anyone with access to your source code repository will have access to your credentials. Best practices include using environment variables (managed via `.env` files for local development), and leveraging secret management services like HashiCorp Vault, AWS Secrets Manager, or Google Secret Manager for production environments.
